project_name: Laguna de Bay Community Carbon Finance Project
pdo: The Community Development Carbon Fund (CDCF) was conceived to simulate the trading of carbon emissions reduction credits as envisioned under the Clean Development Mechanism (CDCF) of the Kyoto Protocol.  The CDCF focuses on purchasing emissions reductions exclusively from small-scale CDM-eligible projects that result in community benefits.  The proposed 'Laguna de Bay Community Carbon Finance Project', will allow the purchase of emissions reduction credits by the CDCF from small-scale watershed interventions implemented under the World Bank Laguna De Bay Institutional Strengthening and Community Participation Project (LISCOP). The main activity of the project will be to implement a set of small-scale projects that both have environmental benefits to the watershed and result in a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.  With technical support from the Laguna Lake Development Authority (LLDA), the projects will be implemented by local governments with community involvement.  Potentially eligible projects include: livestock manure management (biogas methane capture); waste management (small landfill gas, composting facilities and wastewater treatment); and land use change and forestry (agroforestry, urban forestry, riparian revegetation) (see Annex 1 for examples). LLDA will act a the intermediary to undertake carbon trading for the aggregated projects. The project will also establish a mechanism in which the money from the carbon credits could be used for operational costs or new environmental and social investments in the localities implementing these projects.

pdo: This carbon offset project consists of purchase of ERs generated from installation of up to 1,000,000 solar homes systems by Grameen Shakti, the project proponent, to rural users in Bangladesh.  The costs of the SHS can be paid on a cash basis, or can be purchased through a variety of monthly installment plans to maximize participation by increasing affordability.  Grameen Shakti has installed over 75,000 such systems in Bangladesh, and has set up 120 offices for service delivery and performance monitoring. The use of the solar home system technology will displace kerosene and/or diesel for larger systems to meet household lighting and personal electricity needs. The systems are large enough to provide sufficient power for 1-2 lights and a television or radio. One of the major local environmental benefits would be the reduction of household indoor air pollution. Carbon Finance Revenues would allow for the implementation of the program by providing additional resources to capitalize a revolving fund which will combine CF revenues, funds from Grameen, and funds from IDCOL (both grant and loan) to finance the loans to the individual households.  The implementation of this program will increase access in Bangladesh to modern energy sources, where less than 15% of the population is connected to the national electricity grid. The purchase would be made by the World Bank-managed Community Development Carbon Fund (CDCF).   The CDCF provides carbon finance to small-scale CDM projects in the least developed countries and poorer areas of all developing countries and seek to facilitate projects which include, as a measurable output, the provision of goods and services that would lead to improvement in the social welfare of the communities involved in the projects.

project_name: Road Traffic Safety Research in Low and Middle Income Countries Project
pdo: The objectives of the research grant is outlined as follows:a. Gain evidence-based knowledge through research:As laid out in the strategic plan, GRSF and the Bank emphasizes the importance of Research and Development in helping LMICs with capacity development. Of particular interest is the development of data management system and evidence-based knowledgebase for road safety topics in the LMICs.It is expected that with the seed funding provided through the grant, the facility will foster regional-level research activities focused on the keys regions which involve on-going projects within the GRSF. Besides collecting surveillance data, the initiative will also focus on identifying interventions and research analyses in the local regions.b. Research topics aligned with the scope of GRSF activities :The scope of projects funded through the research grant will be expected to be aligned with the overall facility goals as described in the strategic plan document.  These goals follow from the five pillars of road safety as per The Decade Plan of Action created under the auspices of the United Nations Road Safety Collaboration (UNRSC).It will be highly expected that the topics of interest selected for the grant funded projects must involve a balanced mix of activities as represented by the five pillars described below:Pillar 1:  Road Safety Management: strengthening institutional and operational capacity to achieve national road safety objectives; supporting stronger governance and policing;Pillar 2:  Safer Roads and Mobility: improving the planning, design, construction and operation of road networks to ensure safety for all users; encouraging investment in sustainablemodes of transport;Pillar 3:  Safer Vehicles: promoting crashworthiness and empowering consumers with safety information; accelerating introduction and use of proven safety technologies;Pillar 4:  Safer Road Users: putting vulnerable road users, like pedestrians and cyclists, first in policy development; promoting use of seat belts and crash helmets; tackling drink driving; setting and enforcing effective speed limits; improving driver training;Pillar 5:  Post-Crash Response: improving emergency response and trauma care; supporting rehabilitation and care of road injury victims, providing advice, support and legal redress for victims and their families; encouraging third party insurance schemes to finance rehabilitationc. Promote capacity development and dissemination of knowledge:One of the core programs of the facility during 2012-2015 is Capacity Building in the LMICs.  To facilitate this program, the facility and the Bank has developed its own appraisal tool for Road Safety Management Capacity Review.  The review guides the process of shifting from weak to strong institutional management capacity by working with client governments to identify systematic gaps and prioritize investment areas in order to build up activities which advance the development of the lead agency.In this context, one of the objectives for the grant initiative is to develop strong liaisons between the regional research community and the relevant stakeholders in the road safety environment.  The overall goal would be to engage in the development of the researchers so that they are well positioned to actively influence road safety initiatives and capacity building in their respective countries.  Through appropriate dissemination of knowledge to the local government and national agencies, the facility expects to leverage additional investment in road safety activity.The results from this research initiative follow from the objectives which will include the following:1. Insight into the road safety management and capacity development issues in LMIC in the form of evidence-based knowledge2. Fostering colloboration and interaction between researchers in regional academic institutes with the local stakeholders in road safety management.
